description: Adobe Illustrator Creative Cloud is used by both artists and graphic designers to create vector images both in print and digital form. It is typically used to create illustrations, charts, graphs, logos, diagrams, cartoons of real photographs. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
descriptionMD: Adobe Illustrator Creative Cloud is used by both artists and graphic designers to create vector images both in print and digital form. It is typically used to create illustrations, charts, graphs, logos, diagrams, cartoons of real photographs. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
name: Illustrator CC 2017
subtitle: Graphics Design Application

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne introduce Adobe Illustrator CC 2017. They discuss the uses of Illustrator, explain raster and vector information, and review differences of Illustrator on a Mac and Windows operating systems.
episodes.title: Introduction to Illustrator
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:05.327
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.327 --> 00:00:11.147
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.147 --> 00:00:14.890
Hello everyone, and welcome to
this edition of Creative Pro TV.

4
00:00:14.890 --> 00:00:16.240
I'm your host, Vonne Smith.

5
00:00:16.240 --> 00:00:20.480
And today we are bringing you a brand
new series on Illustrator CC.

6
00:00:20.480 --> 00:00:23.250
2017.
Very excited about this product.

7
00:00:23.250 --> 00:00:25.410
It is one of my faves.

8
00:00:25.410 --> 00:00:29.820
And here to help us along is
our expert Ms. Emily Ramsey.

9
00:00:29.820 --> 00:00:30.640
Hello.
How are you.

10
00:00:30.640 --> 00:00:32.390
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

11
00:00:32.390 --> 00:00:34.221
>> Hello. Hello.
I'm feeling very expert-y.

12
00:00:34.221 --> 00:00:36.970
>> [LAUGH]
>> Y'all make me feel so

13
00:00:36.970 --> 00:00:38.310
smart with that title.

14
00:00:38.310 --> 00:00:39.260
I love it.

15
00:00:39.260 --> 00:00:39.960
I love it.

16
00:00:39.960 --> 00:00:40.830
But yes, so excited.

17
00:00:40.830 --> 00:00:42.580
I love Illustrator.

18
00:00:42.580 --> 00:00:43.350
[LAUGH]
>> Yes.

19
00:00:43.350 --> 00:00:44.740
You know, I know,

20
00:00:44.740 --> 00:00:49.970
Illustrator is Is our fave.
We've been together for a while.

21
00:00:49.970 --> 00:00:52.100
>> We have a history.

22
00:00:52.100 --> 00:00:54.800
>> Yes.
So you know how much I love this product

23
00:00:54.800 --> 00:00:58.340
and I know how much you love this product
and this is our introduction Correct.

24
00:00:58.340 --> 00:01:00.490
>> Right.
>> We're gonna start from scratch

25
00:01:00.490 --> 00:01:05.287
like assuming no knowledge,
you don't know what even does.

26
00:01:05.287 --> 00:01:06.098
>> Yeah.
>> And so,

27
00:01:06.098 --> 00:01:09.658
well, you are going to help that.

28
00:01:09.658 --> 00:01:12.238
[LAUGH]
>> It's your job now string over.

29
00:01:12.238 --> 00:01:14.670
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, take over here.

30
00:01:14.670 --> 00:01:15.252
>> Exactly.

31
00:01:15.252 --> 00:01:18.890
Talk about She is great about
interjecting and adding her own tips.

32
00:01:18.890 --> 00:01:22.230
And Vonne was my teacher first, so
that's kind of the funny story here,

33
00:01:22.230 --> 00:01:24.600
that the student becomes the teacher.

34
00:01:24.600 --> 00:01:29.550
But yes, as we discussed,
Illustrator is just a fantastic program.

35
00:01:29.550 --> 00:01:34.390
It's definitely something where, if I can
jump into one of the Adobe programs, and

36
00:01:34.390 --> 00:01:39.190
I can do anything In any program, each
one of them kinda has their own niche.

37
00:01:39.190 --> 00:01:40.730
We'll get into that.

38
00:01:40.730 --> 00:01:42.360
Illustrator is always
gonna be my first choice.

39
00:01:42.360 --> 00:01:44.190
It's just gonna be kinda my go-to program.

40
00:01:44.190 --> 00:01:46.080
Because it's just fun.

41
00:01:46.080 --> 00:01:46.800
It's fun, and

42
00:01:46.800 --> 00:01:50.560
feel like it's one of the ones that
can be a little bit easier to learn.

43
00:01:50.560 --> 00:01:51.890
So that's kind of a nice thing with it.

44
00:01:51.890 --> 00:01:55.070
>> It's slightly more
intuitive in the sense that

45
00:01:55.070 --> 00:01:56.990
>> Paint, you know when we all first got

46
00:01:56.990 --> 00:02:00.580
our computers back in the day, gosh,
I'm showing my age already [LAUGH] Well,

47
00:02:00.580 --> 00:02:03.970
you know you had to like,
I can draw with a paint brush and

48
00:02:03.970 --> 00:02:05.980
you go ahead and pick a color and
things like that.

49
00:02:05.980 --> 00:02:09.970
So I feel like it's kinda
>> Kind of like the new

50
00:02:09.970 --> 00:02:14.350
graduated person if you want to say
from like the little baby Paint and

51
00:02:14.350 --> 00:02:17.110
now it's in illustrator and
what you can do with it.

52
00:02:17.110 --> 00:02:21.160
So I think that's the thing that people
maybe feel more comfortable with.

53
00:02:21.160 --> 00:02:23.410
>> Yes.
>> If you've grown up with computers or

54
00:02:23.410 --> 00:02:24.330
anything like that.

55
00:02:24.330 --> 00:02:26.170
>> Yeah I think that's a great example.

56
00:02:26.170 --> 00:02:30.760
To kind of explain what that means let's
go ahead and take a look at my screen now.

57
00:02:30.760 --> 00:02:32.160
I don't have Illustrator open.

58
00:02:32.160 --> 00:02:34.920
We are looking at something
that I created in Illustrator,

59
00:02:34.920 --> 00:02:37.460
but we're just gonna look at
it as a PDF for right now.

60
00:02:37.460 --> 00:02:41.140
So you kind of are seeing some words,
vector, raster.

61
00:02:41.140 --> 00:02:42.820
It's like, what does that mean?

62
00:02:42.820 --> 00:02:46.250
And if you've never opened up
Illustrator before, You may not know.

63
00:02:46.250 --> 00:02:49.100
Even if you have, you may not
necessarily know what you're creating.

64
00:02:49.100 --> 00:02:53.000
So Illustrator is a vector based program.

65
00:02:53.000 --> 00:02:54.540
Now what does that mean?

66
00:02:54.540 --> 00:02:58.060
Basically, the reason why we use
Illustrator, especially for something like

67
00:02:58.060 --> 00:03:03.310
a logo is because With a vector-based
program, it's all based up on math.

68
00:03:03.310 --> 00:03:07.560
Which you're probably thinking,
like I am, no, I'm in the wrong spot.

69
00:03:07.560 --> 00:03:10.970
This is not why I came to
this job was to do math.

70
00:03:10.970 --> 00:03:13.550
Well, the computer program
does all the math for you, but

71
00:03:13.550 --> 00:03:15.310
it makes everything infinitely scalable.

72
00:03:15.310 --> 00:03:17.670
Now compare that to
something like an image.

73
00:03:17.670 --> 00:03:22.680
So if I'm making an image in Photoshop,
All that is based on pixels.

74
00:03:22.680 --> 00:03:25.330
So if you kinda look at
this raster versus vector.

75
00:03:25.330 --> 00:03:26.810
Kinda looking at what that means.

76
00:03:26.810 --> 00:03:31.350
So raster based images,
also known as bitmap,

77
00:03:31.350 --> 00:03:34.750
are all gonna be things that
really depend on resolution.

78
00:03:34.750 --> 00:03:37.720
And you can think about, okay,
it's built up on this many pixels.

79
00:03:37.720 --> 00:03:41.130
If I try and blow it up you're
gonna get that pixellated effect.

80
00:03:41.130 --> 00:03:44.910
Even if you're new to the concept of
resolution you've probably seen something

81
00:03:44.910 --> 00:03:47.230
that looks a little bit
pixellated before in your life.

82
00:03:47.230 --> 00:03:48.300
Right?

83
00:03:48.300 --> 00:03:48.800
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

84
00:03:48.800 --> 00:03:50.800
>> And you might even see this on social

85
00:03:50.800 --> 00:03:55.970
media or anywhere that you
have images on a screen or

86
00:03:55.970 --> 00:03:58.940
even in a printed material
where it just looks.

87
00:03:58.940 --> 00:03:59.950
Fuzzy-
>> Right.

88
00:03:59.950 --> 00:04:02.800
>> It doesn't look clear and
it's pixellated.

89
00:04:02.800 --> 00:04:07.840
And these are just kind of, I feel,
common terms that nowadays that we

90
00:04:07.840 --> 00:04:12.295
have with anything that involves an image,
that maybe you've even heard of a j.

91
00:04:12.295 --> 00:04:14.205
File we threw some file formats up there.

92
00:04:14.205 --> 00:04:16.725
Don't have to worry about what
each one of them means, but

93
00:04:16.725 --> 00:04:20.375
you might of heard of a jpg file because
we're always sharing pictures and

94
00:04:20.375 --> 00:04:23.935
posting them on Instagram or
Facebook or anywhere else like that and

95
00:04:23.935 --> 00:04:28.340
sharing it like that So,
hopefully you're somewhat familiar with

96
00:04:28.340 --> 00:04:32.930
that type of information of
that particular type of file,

97
00:04:32.930 --> 00:04:37.205
and now you have a fancy term,
that that is a raster based file format.

98
00:04:37.205 --> 00:04:38.610
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly, yeah we're just here for

99
00:04:38.610 --> 00:04:39.655
the fancy terms, really.

100
00:04:39.655 --> 00:04:40.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> So yeah, exactly,

101
00:04:40.960 --> 00:04:42.080
I think Vonne made a good point,

102
00:04:42.080 --> 00:04:44.900
in the digital age, you
>> Probably have something like

103
00:04:44.900 --> 00:04:45.450
a smart phone.

104
00:04:45.450 --> 00:04:50.340
So if I take a picture on my iPhone,
I'm taking a JPEG image to share.

105
00:04:50.340 --> 00:04:52.415
I think it's a JPEG,
I'm gonna go with a JPEG.

106
00:04:52.415 --> 00:04:53.800
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's one of those that

107
00:04:53.800 --> 00:04:55.060
you're looking at here, basically.

108
00:04:55.060 --> 00:04:56.515
So it is something.

109
00:04:56.515 --> 00:04:59.215
>> Something that you're probably
are seeing a little bit more commonly now

110
00:04:59.215 --> 00:05:01.045
than maybe even 10 years ago.

111
00:05:01.045 --> 00:05:03.895
>> Yeah, and maybe,
as we keep on this train, right.

112
00:05:03.895 --> 00:05:08.185
I don't know, with my phone I go
to share picture or I send it,

113
00:05:08.185 --> 00:05:13.205
sometimes it pops up with like, do you
wanna send it as small, medium or large.

114
00:05:13.205 --> 00:05:16.895
You see that a lot, and
you are like, I don't know.

115
00:05:16.895 --> 00:05:18.885
That goes back to the whole
thing that you talked about,

116
00:05:18.885 --> 00:05:24.070
the resolution, All of these
pixels that make up your image.

117
00:05:24.070 --> 00:05:26.850
Well there's amount of pixels, and

118
00:05:26.850 --> 00:05:32.170
how much stuff it has in it
makes the file size bigger.

119
00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:36.750
And so that's why it's asking you what
size, of the small, medium, and large,

120
00:05:36.750 --> 00:05:38.540
because it does something
then it's resampling.

121
00:05:38.540 --> 00:05:39.830
Just go okay sure, that's fine.

122
00:05:39.830 --> 00:05:40.770
Whatever that means.

123
00:05:40.770 --> 00:05:42.690
It's just gonna change
the number of pixels but

124
00:05:42.690 --> 00:05:47.660
it does equate to how large
the file itself goes.

125
00:05:47.660 --> 00:05:50.270
So even if you don't know anything about

126
00:05:50.270 --> 00:05:53.860
all that stuff you've probably seen
that and that's what it's talking about.

127
00:05:53.860 --> 00:05:55.370
>> Yeah,
yeah exactly that's was a great example.

128
00:05:55.370 --> 00:05:58.630
That was the moment I was thinking of
when I thought of you've probably said

129
00:05:58.630 --> 00:05:59.180
the JPEG.

130
00:05:59.180 --> 00:06:01.700
So yes I'm glad you expanded on that.

131
00:06:01.700 --> 00:06:03.950
So yeah that's all our
roster based information.

132
00:06:03.950 --> 00:06:05.840
Now- Illustrator,

133
00:06:05.840 --> 00:06:08.700
the one program we're talking about
here is a vector-based program.

134
00:06:08.700 --> 00:06:11.170
So it's basically kind of
like the opposite of that.

135
00:06:11.170 --> 00:06:12.230
Now there is some rounds and

136
00:06:12.230 --> 00:06:14.120
stuff that can go in there but
that's a different story.

137
00:06:14.120 --> 00:06:15.730
We'll just leave it at that.

138
00:06:15.730 --> 00:06:21.000
So with our vectors, we have everything
known as Pass, there are no pixels.

139
00:06:21.000 --> 00:06:24.010
And as I mentioned,
this is resolution independent.

140
00:06:24.010 --> 00:06:27.060
And also fun fact, I just noticed that
this is spanning onto two lines, and

141
00:06:27.060 --> 00:06:28.580
it's driving me crazy [LAUGH].

142
00:06:28.580 --> 00:06:33.280
So we do not have to work with resolution
like we do in our raster based images.

143
00:06:33.280 --> 00:06:36.350
So it's very different from an image
that you take on your phone or

144
00:06:36.350 --> 00:06:37.640
something like that.

145
00:06:37.640 --> 00:06:40.760
And Illustrator is going to be
the program that we would use.

146
00:06:40.760 --> 00:06:43.510
To create these raster graphics.

147
00:06:43.510 --> 00:06:45.730
Now, when we look at something like that,
okay,

148
00:06:45.730 --> 00:06:49.920
if I kinda move over here we have our
vectors, as I said, vectors are all based

149
00:06:49.920 --> 00:06:53.720
on a mathematical formula that is going
to allow them to be infinitely scalable.

150
00:06:53.720 --> 00:06:56.340
So, I kinda mentioned this example before,

151
00:06:56.340 --> 00:06:59.930
but, Illustrator is a common program
that I would use to create a logo.

152
00:06:59.930 --> 00:07:02.660
Now why would I use
Illustrator to create a logo?

153
00:07:02.660 --> 00:07:06.170
That's probably something that I need to
have in several different sizes, right?

154
00:07:06.170 --> 00:07:10.170
So, you can think about a logo on
something as small as a pen, and then,

155
00:07:10.170 --> 00:07:13.880
okay, a pocket square of a T-shirt,
or kinda labeled on a T-shirt.

156
00:07:13.880 --> 00:07:16.670
Then I need something as
large as a billboard.

157
00:07:16.670 --> 00:07:21.740
I can create that infinitely,
scalable graphic in Illustrator.

158
00:07:21.740 --> 00:07:24.720
If I were trying to make that
up with pixels in Photoshop,

159
00:07:24.720 --> 00:07:26.220
it would get pixellated.

160
00:07:26.220 --> 00:07:28.190
You know,
that resolution would start to look fuzzy.

161
00:07:28.190 --> 00:07:32.240
I think fuzzy is a great word for
describing it.

162
00:07:32.240 --> 00:07:34.100
And a lot of times,
just kind of a fun fact,

163
00:07:34.100 --> 00:07:39.340
often times this utilizes a smaller file
size because we don't have those pixels.

164
00:07:39.340 --> 00:07:44.180
And that resolution that information for
the computer to kind of remember

165
00:07:44.180 --> 00:07:46.880
we are basically all just
working of mathematical formula.

166
00:07:46.880 --> 00:07:50.780
Now I have this graphic here don't
let this you know scare you or

167
00:07:50.780 --> 00:07:54.090
anything like that but I basically just
wanna explain the types of things that we

168
00:07:54.090 --> 00:07:55.360
are gonna be looking at in illustrator.

169
00:07:55.360 --> 00:07:59.900
So I think I mentioned the word
already illustrator, in.

170
00:07:59.900 --> 00:08:02.170
Bleh.
[LAUGH] Illustrator creates what's known

171
00:08:02.170 --> 00:08:03.800
as paths.

172
00:08:03.800 --> 00:08:06.830
So, typically when we're referring
to an object like a triangle,

173
00:08:06.830 --> 00:08:08.370
like what we're looking at here.

174
00:08:08.370 --> 00:08:10.490
Technically it's going to
be referred to as a path.

175
00:08:10.490 --> 00:08:13.830
You may hear us use the word object,
or something kind of similar to that.

176
00:08:13.830 --> 00:08:16.980
And then our paths are based off of these.

177
00:08:16.980 --> 00:08:21.120
Points, so you're going to see that we
have this point here, this point here.

178
00:08:21.120 --> 00:08:21.710
this point here.

179
00:08:21.710 --> 00:08:25.140
A triangle's naturally going to be
three points, a square might be four,

180
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:25.800
something like that.

181
00:08:25.800 --> 00:08:28.320
You can kind of see how that would work,

182
00:08:28.320 --> 00:08:32.600
just based of the idea of just drawing
a square, you have four corners.

183
00:08:32.600 --> 00:08:34.560
You're probably gonna have
a corner in each point.

184
00:08:34.560 --> 00:08:38.580
You could have more,
we'll kinda get into that.

185
00:08:38.580 --> 00:08:39.390
And then we also,

186
00:08:39.390 --> 00:08:43.230
with our color, we typically have
what's known as a fill versus a stroke.

187
00:08:43.230 --> 00:08:46.640
So what we're looking at here,
this is known as our Fill color,

188
00:08:46.640 --> 00:08:48.900
where we have kinda that teal there.

189
00:08:48.900 --> 00:08:52.060
And then we also have this stroke
where we have that kind of

190
00:08:52.060 --> 00:08:53.940
outside border along there with it.

191
00:08:53.940 --> 00:08:56.820
So this is predominantly the type
of thing that you're gonna

192
00:08:56.820 --> 00:08:57.980
be looking at in Illustrator.

193
00:08:57.980 --> 00:09:01.770
>> And here we're really just trying
to introduce you to the terms.

194
00:09:01.770 --> 00:09:02.710
Fill.
Stroke.

195
00:09:02.710 --> 00:09:03.350
Points.

196
00:09:03.350 --> 00:09:04.620
Paths.

197
00:09:04.620 --> 00:09:08.590
Like she said, we'll kinda refer to
them as shapes, cuz it is a shape.

198
00:09:08.590 --> 00:09:11.400
A triangle is a shape, but
technically it's a path.

199
00:09:11.400 --> 00:09:12.890
And even more technically,

200
00:09:12.890 --> 00:09:17.700
it's a closed path versus an open path,
a line that has two points.

201
00:09:17.700 --> 00:09:21.880
Then that's an open path and
this is a closed path.

202
00:09:21.880 --> 00:09:26.590
So you can see in the inside fill,
outside stroke.

203
00:09:26.590 --> 00:09:29.170
And we even say the inside
color sometimes.

204
00:09:29.170 --> 00:09:33.910
We kind of use it interchangeably
of We commonly referred to in our

205
00:09:33.910 --> 00:09:38.630
regular vocabulary versus
the technical definitions of

206
00:09:38.630 --> 00:09:40.730
the make up a path and everything.

207
00:09:40.730 --> 00:09:44.150
And if this is harking back to some of
your geometry lessons and everything and

208
00:09:44.150 --> 00:09:46.700
maybe you're like, gosh I'm so scared.

209
00:09:46.700 --> 00:09:47.980
Geometry actually my favorite

210
00:09:47.980 --> 00:09:49.248
math class ever because
>> Yeah.

211
00:09:49.248 --> 00:09:50.500
[LAUGH]
>> we made shapes.

212
00:09:50.500 --> 00:09:51.820
So I was kinda excited.

213
00:09:51.820 --> 00:09:54.275
The proofs were a little weird but
I still like those too.

214
00:09:54.275 --> 00:09:56.752
[LAUGH]
>> Geometry was not my favorite

215
00:09:56.752 --> 00:09:57.270
subject
>> [LAUGH]

216
00:09:57.270 --> 00:09:59.290
>> In school, and I still like working in

217
00:09:59.290 --> 00:10:03.545
Illustrator Working in Illustrator, so
even if you're not crazy like Vonne and

218
00:10:03.545 --> 00:10:06.935
love geometry, you will still,
I think, enjoy it.

219
00:10:06.935 --> 00:10:11.275
Trust me and I really think Vonne made a
great point earlier, it kind of harks back

220
00:10:11.275 --> 00:10:14.670
to some of that almost childhood
>> Painting,

221
00:10:14.670 --> 00:10:17.070
drawing a square, drawing a triangle.

222
00:10:17.070 --> 00:10:20.030
That's a lot of the stuff, especially
when we're first getting started in

223
00:10:20.030 --> 00:10:21.610
Illustrator, that we're gonna be doing.

224
00:10:21.610 --> 00:10:25.200
So I really think that it will
be kinda fun in that regard.

225
00:10:25.200 --> 00:10:27.190
Now I'm sure we'll have a couple
other things to add, but

226
00:10:27.190 --> 00:10:29.400
I don't wanna miss the common uses here.

227
00:10:29.400 --> 00:10:32.860
Typically, a lot of times people want
to know the common uses of the various

228

different programs, so we went ahead and

00:11:49.170 --> 00:11:54.340

there's no shading and
grades, like right here.

00:12:07.758 --> 00:12:09.803

>> I was like, is she gonna go lingo?

00:12:27.641 --> 00:12:31.518

people do use Photoshop for

You know if I am working on a logo then

then you know maybe if I wanna go ahead.

I just know a lot of people use that for

291

292

293

294

I need to get rid of that big old

296

I would use illustrator

299

the company in it's vector format like

300

a pen, all of our logos,

301

>> And then put it onside a building but

302

304

305

then it all works together.

306

There's a reason why this is a suite

Properly for each job.

309

Now if you're sitting there going
like Ive made those in Photoshop,

310

[LAUGH]
>> It's okay.

311

312

It'd be great, so, yes, excellent points,

I think you're doing very well [LAUGH]

so now we've all been there.

So, when you're first starting out,

Maybe that's kind of

Or even, I've been in your position here

00:16:10.533 --> 00:16:16.311
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Every designer should understand the foundations of digital design - file types, resolution, and color modes.  In this episode, Emily and Vonne give an introduction to these web and graphic design core concepts.
episodes.title: Design 101

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily review the Illustrator workspace. They demonstrate how to work with the panels, toolbox, control panel (also know as the options bar) , and preset workspaces.  They also show how to create custom workspaces as well as zooming techniques and shortcuts.
episodes.title: Navigating in Illustrator

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne demonstrate how to create a new file In Illustrator.  They review file presets, measurement units, artboards, and advanced options. They also explain the importance of saving a file in its native version of Illustrator.
episodes.title: File New

episodes.description: Selecting elements in an Illustrator file is key.  In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to select multiple objects and understand the meaning of the colors shown on the screen. They also review the layers panel and selection shortcuts.
episodes.title: Basic Selections

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to make basic shapes. They review the different tools to make open and closed paths as well as basic formatting.  They also review the meaning and importance the selection and the direct selection tools.
episodes.title: Basic Shapes and Formatting

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily continue with shapes showing the star, line, arc, spiral, rectangular grid, and polar grid tools. They show some handy shortcuts to use with these tools as well as new ways to close paths with the line tool.
episodes.title: Basic Shapes and Formatting Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne review basic text. They discuss the difference between area type and point type and how easy it is now to convert using the selection tool.  They demonstrate basic character and paragraph formatting and how to use the type panels
episodes.title: Basic Text

episodes.description: Color is fun! In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to create swatches using the swatches panel, the color and color guide panels, the swatches libraries, and the color themes panel.
episodes.title: Swatches

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily work with multiple paths.  They show different ways to select multiple paths, grouping and ungrouping objects, and shortcuts for duplicating objects. They also dive into the layers panel, showing how to arrange object stacking order, rename layers, show/hide layers, and selecting objects from the layers panel.
episodes.title: Working with Multiple Paths

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to use different tools to draw paths.  They review the pencil, brush, blob brush, and smooth tool as well as discuss different options associated with each tool.
episodes.title: Freehand Drawing

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne continue with drawing tools, specifically covering how to create a new path versus continue a path and the fine nuances of the pencil and brush tools.
episodes.title: Freehand Drawing Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate and explain the importance of artboards.  They show how to use the artboard tool and the artboard panel to create new artboards and  how to modify options such as resizing, renaming, rearranging the order.
episodes.title: Artboards

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily demonstrate a variety of different tools, panels, and techniques for modifying objects.  They cover the eyedropper tool, transform panel and tool, create rounded corners with the selection tool and transform panel,  and scale stroke and effects options.
episodes.title: Object Transformation

episodes.description: A picture says a thousand words.  In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to add an image to an Illustrator file.  They review the difference between linked and embedded images as well as how raster images behave in a vector file format.
episodes.title: Images

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how different ways to create a gradient using the gradient panel and gradient tool. They also demonstrate how to save gradient swatches, use gradients from the swatch libraries, and how to apply gradients on strokes.
episodes.title: Gradients

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne demonstrate different text effects, covering the type on a path tool , touch  type tool, and create outlines from text.
episodes.title: Text Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to combine shapes in different ways using the pathfinder panel. They define and demonstrate what is a compound path and how to work with them.
episodes.title: Pathfinder and Compound Path

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily introduce the basics of editing paths using the direct selection tool.  They define and introduce Bezier paths, covering the how to add, subtract, and convert points using the different pen tools.
episodes.title: Path Editing Tools

episodes.description: The pen tool is one of the most important tools in Illustrator. In this episode, Emily and Vonne demonstrate how to master the pen tool to create straight and curved paths.
episodes.title: The Pen Tool

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne show how to use the curvature tool - the cousin to the pen tool.
episodes.title: The Curvature Tool

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily introduce different ways to align objects using the align panel, grids and guides, and smart guides.
episodes.title: Aligning Objects

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily continue with aligning objects, specifically covering make guides from a selection, snap to grid and point, view grids, the measure tool, and outline view.
episodes.title: Aligning Objects Part 2

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne add some pizazz to objects by using effects.  They discuss the difference between Photoshop and Illustrator effects in the effects menu as well as 3D effects. They also cover the appearance panel, showing how to edit, add, remove, and rearrange effects  and formatting on fills and strokes of objects
episodes.title: Working with Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to work with the graphic styles panel.  They demonstrate how to find styles in the libraries, break link to style to create custom styles, and create your own graphic style.
episodes.title: Graphic Styles

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to work with clipping masks and opacity masks in Illustrator to create different effects on objects.
episodes.title: Working with Masks

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to use the mesh tool to create realistic shading.  They also cover the recolor artwork command and make a new color group of solid color swatches from a gradient.
episodes.title: Mesh and Recolor

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily take a deeper dive into swatches, specifically covering process versus spot swatches and global swatches. They explain best practices for using these types of swatches for commercial print and formatting artwork in general.
episodes.title: Advanced Swatches

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily discuss how to use and create pattern swatches.  They demonstrate how to create custom pattern swatches, edit existing pattern swatches, find pattern swatches in the swatch libraries, scaling swatches, and modify pattern to repeat on all sides.
episodes.title: Pattern Swatches

episodes.description: Sharing is caring.  In this episode, Vonne and Emily discuss how to share swatches using the Creative Cloud libraries panel.  They also show other ways to share swatches, brushes, styles, and symbols across documents using user defined libraries.
episodes.title: Sharing Swatches

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne demonstrate how to blend paths using the blend command.  They show how to use the blend tool, modify objects and paths in the blend, explore the blend options, and expand into individual paths.
episodes.title: Blend Tool

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily explore how to use symbols, create symbols, edit symbols, symbol libraries, the symbol sprayer tools, and 9 slice scaling with symbols.
episodes.title: Symbols

episodes.description: Emily and Vonne take a deeper look into character and paragraph formatting.  They cover kerning, tracking, leading, indents, space before and after, character and paragraph styles, and other typography elements.  They also cover more about area type with how to control overset text, thread text boxes, and create columns.
episodes.title: Advanced Text

episodes.description: Creating bullets in Illustrator is not as easy as clicking a button.  In this episode, Vonne and Emily demonstrate how to create bullets using glyphs, indents, and tabs
episodes.title: Bullets and Numbering

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne show how to use some lesser known tools for editing paths, specifically the eraser, knife, and scissors tool. They explain best practices for when and how to use these tools and some other techniques to manipulate closed and open paths.
episodes.title: Knife Eraser Sissors

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily continue to demonstrate the many ways to create paths in Illustrator. In this episode, they explore the shaper and the shape builder tool along with their associated tool options.
episodes.title: Shaper and Shape Builder

episodes.description: In this episode, Emily and Vonne transform paths with the offset path command, the width tool, outline stroke, and envelope distort.
episodes.title: Path Transformations

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily continue to transform paths, specifically covering the transform command and how to repeat commands as well as fun ways to use the rotate tool.
episodes.title: Path Transformations Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Emily show how to create vector paths from an image using image trace. They explore the image trace options using the panel and when and why to expand tracing.  They also demonstrate how to create a live paint group and use the live paint tool easily color artwork.
episodes.title: Image Trace and Live Paint

episodes.description: Vonne and Emily explore drawing and creating paths in perspective using the perspective grid tool. They show how to edit grids, choose planes to add paths, and use the perspective grid selection tool.
episodes.title: Perpective Grid

episodes.description: In this final episode of the series, Vonne and Emily show how to complete a project with save and export options.  They show new and old ways to export files to different raster file types for both print and web.  They explore working with web files with the asset export panel, align to pixel grid, and export for screen.
episodes.title: Saving and Exporting
